title.narrative: To scale up the innovative Online System for Farm Monitoring in Central America

description.narrative: The partners of the livelihood programme held a virtual forum to share about project monitoring. Partners feel they need a simple and easy way to do project monitoring and though some have monitoring systems in place, they all feel the need for improvement and innovation. The results of this forum were documented and can be found here: www.cafodca.org. As a result of this forum partners agreed to develop a shared monitoring system for the livelihood programme. Strengthening of monitoring systems was also prioritized by partners in the development of the new programme logframe at the end of 2013. This project aims to use an innovative method for monitoring called Online system for farm monitoring (OSFM). The design and implementation of this VSFM will be new in the region, so SIMAS and partners need to work closely on development and implementation. Due to the complexity and the cost of this system, CAFOD has prioritized two Nicaraguan partners with whom to pilot the new system. Caritas Jinotega (NIC211) and Women Producer Association (ASOMUPRO, NIC214) will be the first partners to implement the new system. The project aims to build capacity for the strategic use of the virtual platform for project monitoring. The virtual platform will use different tools and methods to set-up a monitoring system that will be highly visual. The system will start with a country map (Global Positioning System (GPS)), and then will zoom to the community level, and finally farm level which includes a map, family profile, and 5 SMART indicators that will be chosen with partners through a participatory process. The virtual platform will consolidate information for project monitoring and the system will produce a report designed by partners together with CAFOD. CAFOD's WebPromise also feeds into this system providing project summaries and monitoring matrix for donor information purposes. The system will provide reports to track the advance of the project at three levels - farmers, partners, and donors.
